history.content:
In general I wouldn't recommend taking two homework/project-oriented CS classes at the same time, even if they are 61a and 61b which are relatively easier in workload compared to other CS classes. Even after having taken both those classes, I don't think I could handle the overlap between the two in terms of project due dates, midterm dates, etc. on top of any other classes I would be taking.

tl;dr: Go for it if you want, but I'd strongly recommend against it
You will be able to enroll in both. But work-loadwise I would refer to the student answer :)

children.subject:
I agree -- if you're a transfer and already have programming experience, 61A workload will be light (exams can be tricky though). 61B won't be too bad either. 
I didn't do that combination but I know people who did, and they did well in both courses

Im willing to spend almost all my time studying and doing the projects. I've looked at some of the homework assignment and projects and they seem reasonable. How you ever felt overwhelmed at all during the semester? I also ideally would like to keep a high grade in both courses. Thanks for the advice!

Original commenter:

There were definitely times that I felt overwhelmed by the content (mostly in EE16A; it wasn't hard in retrospect but linear algebra really intimidated me at the time), but I definitely had more than enough time left over for stuff outside of schoolwork. Was also pretty happy with the grades I received in the end.
Thank you very much for the advice!

Just remember that your grades in CS61A and 61B (plus CS70) will be used in your application to declare CS and your EE16A grade will not be. I would recommend enrolling in a breadth that you need to complete so that you will be able to drop a class, if needed. You need to be enrolled in 13 units/semester.

I took this combination last year along with a DeCal and DES INV course and thought it was fine. (also came in with programming experience)

My advice would be to ignore all the advice you receive and make a decision for yourself: the lower division CS experience varies wildly by student (especially for 61A + B), and you're (usually) the best judge of your own abilities. Take a look at past midterms/labs/projects: how difficult are they? How much time would you need to spend each week to master the material, and how much time can you put in?

history.content:
I am an incoming transfer with programming experience. I am thinking of having this as my schedule for the fall semester. DeNero/Hilfinger for 61A and Hilfinger for 61B. Does this schedule seem like too much or is it completely doable?

I've also had 61B partially completed at my cc but am choosing to take it again to reinforce my knowledge and to do the projects. Would there be an issue enrolling in 61A/B concurrently?

I appreciate any advice!
history.subject: [ADVICE] CS 61A, 61B, ee16A in the fall.
